results.title: Bombay milk scheme
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description: To improve the supply and quality of milk in Bombay, the Government began construction in 1948 of a dairy farm and passed a law requiring that all cattle herds be moved outside the city limits. The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations sent an expert in animal husbandry and a dairy technologist to work with local officials and experts.

results.title: Bomb threat: plan, don't panic
results.creator_credit: William Brose Productions and William Brose
results.brief_description: Bomb threats, once almost unknown, have dramatically increased in number. The best defence is a plan carefully evolved to fit your organisation. This film is designed for all levels of management and employees. The film is open-ended to promote audience involvement and discussion.

results.title: Bomb threat strategy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Safetycare”
Preventative measures, what to look for, search procedures, assessing the threat, the telephone call, when to evacuate and the correct evacuation procedures are the key points covered in this video.

results.title: Bolivia: the tin mountain
results.creator_credit: David Elstein, Thames Television and Martin Smith
results.brief_description: A moving presentation showing the desperate poverty in the lives of the tin miners of Bolivia. Notes the problems of lack of capital, absentee ownership of the tin mines, market forces and the political system which influence the prices of tin and hence the life style of the miners. Narrated by Jonathan Dimbleby. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: BOLD = Blind outdoor leisure development
results.brief_description: At Aspen, in the Rocky Mountains, U.S.A., an organisation called Blind Outdoor Leisure Development enables blind people to participate in many sports. With experienced guides, 500 blind people are involved in all kinds of sports, including skiing, ice-skating, horseriding, fishing, mountain climbing, rafting in the Colorado rapids, and experiencing wildlife. Narrated by John Denver. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Boiler house practice
results.creator_credit: C W S Film Unit and George Wynn
results.brief_description: This film was made to encourage economy in the use of fuel through efficient boiler house practice. Points mentioned include: correct tools, methods of hand-firing, control of air-flow, care of mechanical stokers, regular cleaning of heating surfaces, the necessity for careful maintenance generally. Particular emphasis is placed on the part of the fireman.

results.title: Bogota: fragments of a city
results.creator_credit: Manuel Rivos, International Film Foundation and Jan-henk Kleijn
results.brief_description: A young photographer walks through the streets of Colombia’s capital, capturing images of life in what he characterises as a sad and old city. His expressive sepia coloured stills of people and his personal impressions and reactions heard in voice-over form the focus of this film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Manuel Rivos, International Film Foundation and Jan-henk Kleijn

results.title: Bodywork
results.creator_credit: Glenys Rowe, Central Park Films and David Caesar
results.brief_description: Confessions from the funeral trade. There are no cadavers in Bodywork, because the film is about the living. David Caesar introduces us to the workers of the death industry rather than the clients. What they talk about is fascinating; how they say it is riveting. The various stages of mortuary work are explained by people who take pride in their profession. “Bodywork” is a thoroughly illuminating and entertaining film. This film won the Best Documentary Award at the 1989 Melbourne Film Festival.
